occurrences.line_text: Whose names and nations were too long to tell,
In which I daily dying am too long.
Well did the Squire perceiue him selfe too weake,
Which lawlesse multitude him comming too
Vppon the carkasse of some beast too weake,
For I him find to be too proudly fed.
The rest my selfe too readily can spell.
And then too well beleeu'd, that which tofore
If he too rashly to his charet drew,
Deliuer him his owne, ere yet too late,
Too much am I to blame for that faire Maide,
Why hath thy hand too bold it selfe embrewed
An hart, not carried with too curious eyes,
And him to beare, she thought it thing too base.
They fall too short of our fraile reckonings,
Too greatly grieue at any his vnlucky case.
Of euery wight, that were not too infest,
That him too light of credence did mislead,
As I it past, that were too great a shame,
Whose sundry parts were here too long to tell:
Gan cry to them aloud, to helpe ere all too late.
Would be on earth too great a blessednesse,
They fall to strokes, the frute of too much talke:
Or if it to reuenge he were too weake,
Most like that virgin true, which for her knight him took.
And took on him the robe of Emperoure:
Eftsoones he tooke that miscreated faire,
Those two he tooke, and in a secret bed,
And tell, both who ye be, and who that tooke your part.
Thensforth I tooke Duessa for my Dame,
Her vp he tooke, too simple and too trew,
From her faire eyes he tooke commaundement,
And in her selfe-lou'd semblance tooke delight;
And backe returning tooke her wonted way,
He by a priuie Posterne tooke his flight,
From whence he tooke his well deserued name:
Then vp he tooke the slombred sencelesse corse,
When all was past, tooke vp his forlorne weed,
Then tooke that Squire an horne of bugle small,
Then tooke the angrie witch her golden cup,
And fiercely tooke his trenchand blade in hand,
And knighthood tooke of good Sir Huons hand,
Who in her loosenesse tooke exceeding ioy;
Of his seuenfolded shield away it tooke,
With his sad guide; himselfe she tooke a boord,
But she so fast pursewd, that him she tooke,
Who on him tooke the royall Diademe,
He hearkned, and his armes about him tooke,
They tooke them both, & both them strongly bound
They courteous conge tooke, and forth together yode.
Great shame and sorrow of that fall he tooke;
They tooke their steeds, & forth vpo[n] their iourney went.
They both vprose and tooke their readie way
For thy great care she tooke, and greater feare,
Of name Cayr-Merdin cald, they tooke their way:
First rooting tooke; but what thing it mote bee,
Both speare she tooke, and shield, which hong by it:
She with him bound, and Congï¿½ tooke withall.
Who lately left the same, and tooke this way:
Vp they them tooke, each one a babe vptooke,
All which, she of him tooke with countenance meeke and mild.
And courtly seruices tooke no delight,
About her sclender wast, he tooke in hand,
The thing it selfe. In hand she boldly tooke
Then tooke he him yet trembling sith of late,
Which they so much mistooke, they tooke delight
Her vp they tooke, and with them home her led,
And like a winged horse he tooke his flight,
Though for her sake they all that perill tooke,
These three that hardie chalenge tooke in hand,
And Cambel tooke Cambina to his fere,
Then tooke the bold Sir Satyrane in hand
They tooke their steeds, and forward thence did pas
The same he tooke, and with a riband new,
Eftsoones the Prince tooke downe those Ladies twaine
Then tooke he that same Dwarfe, and him compeld
He yeelded, and her tooke; so stinted all their strife.
And loe his hindparts, whereof heed I tooke,
That of no worldly thing he tooke delight;
He lately tooke, and sithence kept as thrall.
Shall find that from the point, where they first tooke
That since the time they first tooke the Sunnes hight,
In goodly wise, whereof it tooke his name,
And by the other markes, which of his shield he tooke.
Nor tooke away his loue, but his owne proper good.
He tooke it vp, and thence with him did beare,
Her selfe then tooke he by the sclender wast,
Thereafter all that mucky pelfe he tooke,
Him by the bright embrodered hedstall tooke:
Which as our owne we tooke, and so it thought.
Him Talus tooke out of perplexitie,
And as her vassall him to thraldome tooke.
Then tooke the Amazon this noble knight,
Yet he it tooke in his owne selfes despight,
But tooke her steede, and thereon mounting light,
It as a token of good fortune tooke.
Or that some pensiuenesse to heart she tooke.
That she to hunt the beast first tooke in hond;
Or in the compasse of his clouches tooke;
But he then tooke it vp, and held fast in his hand.
Ere proofe it tooke, discouered was betymes,
Vnder Alcides club, streight tooke his flight
He tooke her vp forby the lilly hand,
And on his shield tooke hold with all her might,
Who nought was terrifide, but greater courage tooke.
Which thereon seizing, tooke no great effect;
He tooke his leaue of her, there left in heauinesse.
So both tooke goodly leaue, and parted seuerall.
Me first he tooke, vnhable to withstond;
His heart gan faint, and streight he tooke his flight
Which tooke in hand her quarrell to maintaine;
Tooke in foule scorne, that I such fault did find,
Vpon him tooke the roiall high degree,
He tooke that Ladie, and her vp did rayse
And tooke with him the head, the signe of shame.
Then vp he tooke her twixt his armes twaine,
So downe he tooke his Lady in distresse,
They tooke it well, and thanked God for all,
Then tooke he vp betwixt his armes twaine
He tooke him selfe vnto this Hermitage,
Of that good Hermite both they tooke their leaue,
Tooke surer hould, and from his horses backe
That at aduantage him at last he tooke,
And tooke their gentle offer: so adowne
In shepheards weed, and in his hand he tooke,
Tooke Coridon, and set him in his place,
Her flowry garlond tooke from her owne head,
Which with the rest they tooke not long agoe,
Thereto they soone agreed, and earnest tooke,
He tooke it vp, and in his mantle wound;
And rage to quaile, he tooke a muzzell strong
The good Sir Pelleas him tooke in hand,
Life from Sansfoy thou tookst, Sansloy shall fro[m] thee take.
Whipping her horse, did with his smarting toole
Those deadly tooles, which in her hand she held,
And in the meane vouchsafe her honorable toombe.
Fit to adorne the dead, and decke the drery toombe.
Yet ere he fled, he with his tooth impure
And on the top a Diall told the timely howres.
From top to toe no place appeared bare,
Vpon the top of all his loftie crest,
On top of greene Selinis all alone,
High growing on the top of rocky clift,
On top whereof aye dwelt the ghastly Owle,
On top whereof a sacred chappell was,
Gan faile, but by her helpe the top at last he wonne.
And on the top of all I do espye
Was mounted high in top of heauen sheene,
There stood a stately Mount, on whose round top
Vpon the top of Mount Olympus hight,
From top of Hemus, by him heaped hye;
Next him was Feare, all arm'd from top to toe,
Whose top was arm'd with many an yron hooke,
And on the top thereof a spacious plaine
T'oppose against his powre, he forth issued
Through the tops of the high trees she did descry
And all their tops bright glistering with gold,
And in their tops the soring hauke did towre,
Quite topside turuey, and the pagan hound
And high her burning torch set vp in heauen bright.
And quenched quite, like a consumed torch,
Eftsoones long waxen torches weren light,
His monstrous scalpe downe to his teeth it tore,
His ruefull shriekes and gronings, often tore
That high trees ouerthrew, and rocks in peeces tore.
As it with mightie leuers had bene tore:
Him rudely rent, and all to peeces tore:
Returning to his bed in torment great,
Such restlesse passion did all night torment
The cursed creatures doe eternally torment.
But her deare heart with anguish did torment,
In which his torment often was so great,
Now after all his torment well withstood,
That neuer man such mischiefes did torment;
How shamefully that Maid he did torment.
And the weake mind with double woe torment?
Yet still he sat, and inly did him selfe torment.
But nathelesse he did her still torment,
These flames, these flames (he cryde) do me torment.
Fast flying, there eternall torment found,
Backe to the world, bad liuers to torment:
Or euill spright, that in her doth such torment breed.
So doth he punish her and eke himselfe torment.
Then for the burning torment, which he felt,
What equall torment to the griefe of mind,
And then againe she did her selfe torment,
He sore doth wound, and bite, and cruelly torment.
And beat her breast, and piteously her selfe torment.
To make them to endure the pains, did them torment.
A grieuous gout tormented him full sore,
Lo Tantalus, I here tormented lye:
Infinite moe, tormented in like paine
In her tormented bodie to embrew:
That when the wicked feend his Lord tormented,
All trauellers tormented are with paine:
Tormented sore, could not containe it still,
But it tormented her both day and night:
Tormenteth, and doth plonge in dolefull plight,
There he tormenteth her most terribly,
Ah God, what horrour and tormenting griefe
Die had she rather in tormenting griefe,
The great tormenting griefe, that for her sake
Whereas the damned ghosts in torments fry,
The damned ghosts, that doe in torments waile,
Whilest deadly torments do her chast brest rend,
His sandales were with toilesome trauell torne,
Vpon a snaggy Oke, which he had torne
The faire Medina with her tresses torne,
The noble braunch from th'antique stocke was torne
Against that Knight, ere he him well could torne
And torne in peeces by Alcides great.
Either the Prince in peeces to haue torne
Torne all to rags, and rent with many a wound,
Of his owne steedes was all to peeces torne,
And vnderneath his breech was all to torne and iagged.
And makes her ribs to cracke, as they were torne,
So hauing from his crauen bodie torne
Yet is the bottle leake, and bag so torne,
Gainst him, that had them long opprest with tort,
It was complaind, that thou hadst done great tort
A simple mayd, and worke so haynous tort,
Ne each of other feared fraud or tort,
By tortious wrong, or whom bereau'd of right.
And tortious powre, without respect or measure.
Gainst tortious powre and lawlesse regiment,
Purchast through lawlesse powre and tortious wrong
But this fell Tyrant, through his tortious powre,
But yet by torture he would her constraine
Her forward still with torture did constraine,
For terrour of the tortures manifold,
With all the tortures, that he could deuize,
That troublous dreame gan freshly tosse his braine,
And euery tender part does tosse and turne:
For whose deare sake so many troubles her did tosse.
Where haue you left your Lord, that could so well you tosse?
Then gan he tosse aloft his stretched traine,
Long were to tell the troublous stormes, that tosse
Doe tosse, that it will stonne thy feeble braines,
In her right hand a firebrand she did tosse
And tosse the deepes, and teare the firmament,
Which tosse the rest in daungerous disease?
Nought sparing them, the more did tosse and teare,
So tossed was in fortunes cruell freakes;
As a tall ship tossed in troublous seas,
Wherein my feeble barke is tossed long,
Oft tossed with his stormes, which therein still remaine.
But tossed in her troublous minde, what way
Which had in many fortunes tossed beene,
To tossen speare and shield, and to affrap
Which tosseth states, and vnder foot doth tread
Tossing and turning them withouten end;
Tossing them like a boate amid the mayne,
After long tossing in the seas distrest,
Is tost with troubled sights and fancies weake,
By traynes into new troubles to haue tost:
Long tost with stormes, and bet with bitter wind,
One night, when she was tost with such vnrest,
Aye me to see that gentle maide so tost.
And tost the Paynim, without feare or awe;
From side to side they tost him here and there,
Like as a ship with dreadfull storme long tost,
And there all night himselfe in anguish tost,
Like him that being long in tempest tost,
And she her selfe in stormie surges tost;
As if he would haue tottered to one side.
And tottred like two towres, which through a tempest quooke.
Though true as touch, though daughter of a king,
That well he could not touch, nor go, nor stand:
What euer thing does touch his rauenous pawes,
Ne durst approch him nigh, to touch, or once assay.
Warnd him not touch, for yet perhaps remaynd
The inner garment fret, not th'vtter touch;
Of euery finest fingers touch affrayd;
Decline her head, & touch her crouper with her crowne.
Whiles neither lets the other touch the soyle,
For hardly could he come the carle to touch,
And him to touch with falshoods fowle attaint,
With the neare touch whereof in tender hart
He neare was touched in his noble spright,
And euerie limbe that touched her did quake:
And touched was with secret wrath and shame
But most she touched was with griefe entire,
And touched with intire affection, nigh him drew.
But she, whose Princely breast was touched nere
Was inly touched with compassion deare,
Which when he heard, he inly touched was
Was touched with compassion entire,
That it would tempt a man to touchen there:
Touching her loues successe, her lingring smart.
That euer to haue toucht her, I did deadly rew.
Was toucht with soft remorse and pitty rare;
Was toucht, and mighty courage mollifide,
As was Aegerie, that Numa tought;
Whose case when as the carefull Dwarfe had tould,
O but (quoth she) great griefe will not be tould,
But his most hideous head my toung to tell
Toung hates to tell the rest, that eye to see abhord.
To which his flowing toung, and troublous spright
Ne toung did tell, ne hand these handled not,
His foltring toung with pangs of drerinesse,
With yron toungs, and sprinckled oft the same
With costly clothes of Arras and of Toure,
On th'other side an high rocke toured still,
Which they far off beheld from Troian toures,
Both slow and swift a like do serue my tourne,
So comes it now to Florimell by tourne,
Into a Foxe himselfe he first did tourne;
Now had faire Cynthia by euen tournes
Well could he tourney and in lists debate,
At tilt or tourney, or like warlike game,
And as a Beare whom angry curres haue touzd,
That he thereon should spin both flax and tow;
Threatning to yoke them tow & tame their corage stout.
Now (sayd the Lady) draweth toward night,
The Redcrosse knight toward him crossed fast,
And toward them full matronely did pace.
He either enuying my toward good,
His toward perill and vntoward blame,
He vp gan lift toward the azure skies,
Toward the land; two riuers bound the rest.
Two armed Knights, that toward them did pace,
With speare in rest, and toward him did fare,
The warie fowle that spies him toward bend
He gan to faint, toward the battels end,
That toward them his course seem'd to apply,
But toward th'end Sir Arthegall renewed
Thence she them brought toward the place, where late
All these together marched toward Proteus hall.
Of all this lower world, toward his dissolution.
She chaunst to meete toward th'euen-tide
Toward the Castle, where if need constraine,
Toward the same incessantly did ronne,
Which breaking of he toward them did pace,
So forth he drew much gold, and toward him it driue.
Out of the wood he rose, and toward them did go.
And towardes him with dreadfull fury praunce;
Was guests to welcome, towardes him did pas:
So towardes them they coasted, to enquire
Towardes him runs, and with rude flaring lockes
And seeing him so fiercely towardes make,
Gan fairely couch his speare, and towards ride:
She weend it was, and towards him gan ryde:
And with faire fearefull humblesse towards him shee came.
One pricking towards them with hastie heat,
And towards it a broad high way that led,
And ran towards the far rebownded noyce,
A Lyon spyes fast running towards him,
So towards old Syluanus they her bring;
And towards him they gan in hast to ride,
More greedy they of newes, fast towards him do crosse.
He marched forth towards that castle wall;
An armed knight towards them gallop fast,
They seeing Vna, towards her gan wend,
So dreadfully he towards him did pas,
And fresh encounter towards him addrest:
Tho when as still he saw him towards pace,
And towards gan a deadly shaft aduaunce,
A varlet running towards hastily,
An armed knight, that towards him fast ran,
But bent his hastie course towards the idle flood.
At last he spide, where towards him did pace
Till that they spide, where towards them did pace
To stere the boate towards that dolefull Mayd,
Ran towards, to deuoure those vnexpected guests.
They spide a knight, that towards pricked faire,
And hasting towards him gan faire perswade,
She mightily auentred towards one,
Her fearfull feete towards the bowre she moued;
With hastie gallop towards her did ryde;
And soueraine fauour towards chastity,
Sir Satyrane him towards did addresse,
And euer faine he towards them would goe,
How towards her he rusht, and smiled at his pryde.
Two other knights, that towards them did ply
Towards them driuing like a storme out sent.
Gan towards them to pricke with eger speede,
A Knight soft ryding towards them they spyde,
At length they spide, where towards them with speed
And towards th'end, grew greater in his might,
She fiercely towards him her selfe gan dight,
Towards which coast her loue his way addrest.
One comming towards her with hasty speede:
Towards her chamber; at which dreadfull stound
And by which way they towards it should trace.
Towards my Ladies presence by you ment,
Towards the westerne brim begins to draw,
Which towards him with all their powre did ryde,
She towards him in hast her selfe did draw,
Towards a Ladie, whom with vsage kind
Towards all womenkind them kindly to behaue.
Till towards night they came vnto a plaine,
They towards euening wandring euery way,
But one still towards shew'd her selfe afore;
He chaunst one comming towards him to spy,
Tho when as towards darksome night it drew,
And robd of reason, towards her him bore,
As still are wont t'annoy the walled towne,
O lamentable fall of famous towne,
Proud Priams towne. So wise is Nereus old,
By many a city, and by many a towne,
Threw many threats, if they the towne did win,
All night likewise, they of the towne in fright,
Fled fast into the towne, and her sole victor left.
Both goodly Castle, and both goodly Towne,
And all the people both of towne and land,
And all the damzels of that towne in ray,
And forward marched to a towne in sight.
That doth despise the dainties of the towne.
In readinesse, forth to the Towne-gate went;
And from the citties to the townes him prest,
And from the townes into the countrie forsed,
Out of their townes did round about him throng,
Like the old ruines of a broken towre,
That could haue ouerthrowne a stony towre,
And that bright towre all built of christall cleene,
And this bright Angels towre quite dims that towre of glas.
And this bright Angels towre quite dims that towre of glas.
The brasen towre in which my parents deare
Ne backward shrinke, but as a stedfast towre,
Whereof king Nine whilome built Babell towre;
Nor that proud towre of Troy, though richly guilt,
And likest is vnto that heauenly towre,
But who does wonder, that has red the Towre,
And through the roofe of her strong brasen towre
And in their tops the soring hauke did towre,
High lifted vp were many loftie towres,
Both loftie towres and highest trees hath rent,
Whose wals and towres were builded high and strong
Her loftie towres vnto the starry sphere,
Towres, Cities, Kingdomes ye would ruinate,
And stately towres of Ilion whilome
In which were many towres and castels set,
And tottred like two towres, which through a tempest quooke.
With many towres, and tarras mounted hye,
My cities sackt, and their sky-threating towres
Her stately towres, and buildings sunny sheene;
These towring rocks, which reach vnto the skie,
Whether high towring, or accoasting low,
Her chast hart had subdewd, to learne Dame pleasures toy.
To dally thus with death, is no fit toy,
But when he saw her toy, and gibe, and geare,
A foe of folly and immodest toy,
But other some could not abide to toy,
Ne lend we leisure to his idle toy:
Oft-times amo[n]gst the wanton Nymphs to sport and toy.
Whiles thus she talked, and whiles thus she toyd,
In combats of sweet loue, and with his mistresse toyed.
And flowes in pleasures, and vaine pleasing toyes,
And other whiles vaine toyes she would deuize
To fly about, playing their wanton toyes,
That euer mixt their song with light licentious toyes.
And pleasing toyes he would her entertaine,
But like to Angels playing heauenly toyes;
Before her stands her knight, for whom she toyld so sore.
They did about their businesse sweat, and sorely toyld.
Then all the world is lost, and we in vaine haue toyld.
Sleepe after toyle, port after stormie seas,
And you good Sir, I wote that of your toyle,
High heauen behold the tedious toyle, ye for me take.
With heat, toyle, wounds, armes, smart, & inward fire
With greedie malice and importune toyle,
Whose mariners and merchants with much toyle,
But neither toyle nor trauell might her backe recoyle.
This is the Port of rest from troublous toyle,
And yet through languour of her late sweet toyle,
But there doe toyle and trauell day and night,
Or what needs her to toyle, sith fates can make
Her heart nigh broken was with weary toyle,
All woxen weary of their iournall toyle:
And gaine a feastfull guerdon of their toyle,
Like as a withered tree through husbands toyle
And bad them leaue their labours and long toyle,
So much the more her griefe, the more her toyle:
Yet neither toyle nor griefe she once did spare,
Ioyous to see her safe after long toyle.
Of Britomart after long tedious toyle,
So was his toyle the more, the more that was his care.
Of warres delight, and worlds contentious toyle,
And toyle endured, sith I left him last
My limbes in euery shade, to rest from toyle,
Ne ought was tyred with his endlesse toyles,
As he his toylesome teme that way did guyde,
And soone leaue off this toylesome wearie stoure;
His tyred armes for toylesome wearinesse,
Through toylesome heate and labour of her weary fight.
(Said she) that taken haue this toylesome paine
Tho wexing weary of that toylesome paine,
In seas of troubles and of toylesome paine,
His former paine, and wypt away his toylsoms weat.
And fild his ballaunce full of idle toys:
Thus long they trac'd, and trauerst to and fro,
Thus long they trac'd and trauerst to and fro,
Vnlike to men, who euer as they trace,
That no'te without an hound fine footing trace.
Through which a beaten broad high way did trace,
And them beside an aged Sire did trace,
She wounded had, the same along did trace
If any tract of him or tydings they mote trace.
Went forth in hast, and did her footing trace
But more she meruaild that no footings trace,
